text.p:
Given their strong nonlinearity, direct coupling to external light fields and highly compact nature,
semiconductor microcavities represent a promising candidate for quantum information processing. Quantum
squeezing [1] and quantum complementarity [2] have been experimentally reported, while entanglement has
been predicted theoretically [3]. We study two further quantum applications of polaritons: single photon source
generation and multimode entanglement.

Although simply reducing the intensity of a laser source can be used to create single photons, high
quality sources of single photons require nonlinearity to overcome Poisson statistics. In semiconductor
microcavities, the polariton blockade effect has been predicted to give single photons if the nonlinearity between
two polaritons is strong [4]. Unfortunately, existing polariton systems demonstrate a weaker nonlinearity than
that required for this effect. Whilst advances in growth technology could increase the nonlineariy available, we
have found that in a two coupled mode system a significant single photon statistics can still be found despite the
use of moderate polariton-polariton interaction strengths [5]. This effect is due to a quantum interference [6].
Polaritons also hold great potential for the realization of highly entangled states. We consider schemes
for the entanglement of multiple polariton states, which represent the necessary cluster states for one-way
quantum computational schemes [7].

When the value of a multimode Bell type inequality drops below 1, the state of the system
is entangled. As a function of pump intensity, this is shown with full density matrix calculations (spots) and
Heisenberg equations (curve).The different curves show the effect of increasing pure dephasing from polariton-
phonon scattering.
